data.title: 25 of the Most Covered Songs in Music History
data.meta_description: If there were an award for most covered artists of all time, The Beatles would undoubtedly be a top contender.
data.text:
Unlike movies, where itâs rare that a second (or third) attempt at remaking a film can ever matchâlet alone topâthe original, music is a different sort of creative beast. Just because The Beatles did a bang-up job on one song doesnât mean that Joan Baez or Elvis Presley couldnât do the same tune justice in their own unique way (which is a very good thing, as The Beatlesâs catalog is one of the most copied in music history).

While not an exhaustive list, here are 25 of the most covered songs in music history.

1. âYesterdayâ // The Beatles

âYesterdayâ has been covered more than 2200 times, with Joan Baez, Liberace, Frank Sinatra, Elvis Presley, En Vogue, and Boyz II Men among the many (many) artists to put their own spin on the song. Plus, you know youâve made it as a band when even Daffy Duck gets in on the action.

2. â(I Canât Get No) Satisfactionâ // The Rolling Stones

This classic Rolling Stones song has been redone by a diverse array of artists, including Jimi Hendrix, Devo, and Vanilla Ice. It was also famously covered by Britney Spears at the 2000 MTV Video Music Awards before she launched into âOops! I Did It Again.â

3. âLove Me Tenderâ // Elvis Presley

âLove Me Tenderâ was a hit long before Elvis and songwriter Ken Darby changed the title and the lyrics. The song became popular during the Civil War under the name âAura Lee,â but it was the version that was altered in 1956 that would go on to become covered by other musicians time and time again. The range of artists who have covered itâeveryone from Julie Andrews and Johnny Cash to Jim Morrisonâshows just how versatile it is.

4. âBillie Jeanâ // Michael Jackson

When âBillie Jeanâ was released in 1983, it became the first song to hit #1 on four pop charts simultaneously. The song is still one of MJâs most popular and most covered, with at least 143 recorded versions floating around out there. (And yes, that includes the Chipmunks.)

5. âEleanor Rigbyâ // The Beatles

A somewhat surprising choice, considering The Beatlesâs other hits, but itâs been covered 131 times by artists such as Ray Charles, Tony Bennett, Aretha Franklin, Kansas, and Swedish industrial metal band Pain.

More Articles About Music:

6. âMy Wayâ // Frank Sinatra

The ironic part of Sinatraâs âMy Wayâ is how many of the artists who covered the song didnât do it Frankâs way. But with at least 152 covers in existence (including one from actor Gary Oldman when he appeared as Sid Vicious in Sid & Nancy), a little variation is to be expected. (Just avoid doing a karaoke version.)

7. âBridge Over Troubled Waterâ // Simon & Garfunkel

According to Secondhand Songs, there are nearly 600 versions of this Simon & Garfunkel ballad. Released in January 1970, the sweeping epic was immediately covered by both Johnny Mathis and Stevie Wonder just a few weeks later.

8. âAinât No Sunshineâ // Bill Withers

Withers wrote âAinât No Sunshineâ while he was working as an aircraft mechanic. The hit song propelled him onto the music scene and weâve heard versions ever since, including from Paul McCartney, Adam Levine, and DMX.

Fun fact: Withers didnât originally intend to say the famous âI knowâ line 26 times; it was just a placeholder for lyrics that he eventually planned to pen. But a gaggle of legendary musicians happened to be in the studio while he was recording, including Graham Nash, Stephen Stills, and Booker T., and they told him it was great. âThey were all these people with all this experience and all these reputations, and I was this factory worker in here just sort of puttering around. So when their general feeling was, 'leave it like that,â I left it like that,â Withers said.

9. âHallelujahâ // Leonard Cohen

After being featured in every TV drama and sweeping cinematic moment, Leonard Cohen himself once agreed with a suggestion that maybe it was time to retire âHallelujahâ and its endless cover versions.

Cohen also found it amusing that the song received so much attention, because his record label refused to release the album it was originally on. He later changed his mind about the covers, saying, âonce or twice Iâve felt maybe I should lend my voice to silencing it, but on second thought no, Iâm very happy that itâs being sung.â

10. âAnd I Love Herâ // The Beatles

The original song is from one of The Beatlesâs earlier albums, A Hard Dayâs Night, and has since been reworked by Bob Marley, Smokey Robinson, Sarah Vaughan, Barry Manilow, and Vince Gill, among numerous others.

11. âTime After Timeâ // Cyndi Lauper

The fact that this â80s staple has been covered 270 times isnât such a surprise, but the wide-ranging styles of those covers are. Check out Miles Davis wailing on his version at the Munich Philharmonic in 1988.

12. âI Walk the Lineâ // Johnny Cash

The Man in Blackâs gravelly hit has been covered nearly 200 times, but honestly, that seems low. However, the quality is high: Artists who have covered âI Walk the Lineâ include Dolly Parton, Dean Martin, Halsey, the Everly Brothers, Los Lonely Boys, Waylon Jennings and... Leonard Nimoy?

13. âGod Only Knowsâ // The Beach Boys

God only knows how many times this 1966 song by the Beach Boys has been covered, but it was more than 200 at last count. Lyle Lovettâs live version at the 2007 Kennedy Center Honors, where Brian Wilson was honored, stands out to Wilson as the best rendition ever: âI thought Lyle Lovettâs version was the best version I ever heard, including the Beach Boysâ. The most loving, beautiful version Iâve ever heard. Unbelievable.â

14. âHouse of the Rising Sunâ // The Animals

It may come as a surprise to know that âHouse of the Rising Sunâ is actually not by The Animals originally, although their legendary folk-rock version is arguably the most well-known. âHouseâ is a traditional folk song with roots going back to early 20th century Appalachia, and maybe even earlier. Everyone whoâs anyone has covered this classic, including Dolly Parton, Woody Guthrie, Bob Dylan, Jimi Hendrixâand even Andy Griffith.

15. âCry Me A Riverâ // Julie London

This jazzy number from 1955 has been covered by a huge range of people, including Barbra Streisand, Joe Cocker, Aerosmith, Rick Astley, BjÃ¶rk, Merle Haggard, and Olivia Newton-John.

16. âImagineâ // John Lennon

Musical stalwarts like Joan Baez, Ray Charles, Elton John, David Bowie, and Queen have all given their own personal touch to âImagine.â And in recent years, the likes of Pink, Lady Gaga, and Avril Lavigne have joined the long list of artists who have attempted to make the John Lennon classic their own.

17. âAll of Meâ // John Legend

A more contemporary song on the list, John Legendâs 2013 song about then-fiancÃ©e Chrissy Teigen was once dubbed âYouTubeâs Most-Covered Song.â Not a big fan of ballads? Donât worry; there are plenty of other flavors out there, like Tiestoâs EDM remix.

18. âOver The Rainbowâ // Judy Garland

One of the most frequently performed songs during American Idol auditions has also been covered by plenty of musical greats. Non-Idol cover versions include Willie Nelson, Patti LaBelle, Eva Cassidy, Eric Clapton, Chet Atkins, Tori Amos, Me First & The Gimme Gimmes, and Israel Kamakawiwo'ole. That last version is the Hawaiian rendition thatâs mixed with âWhat a Wonderful World,â and has gotten a lot of play in recent years.

19. âSummertimeâ // Abbie Mitchell

Abbie Mitchell is the person who originally sang âSummertimeâ in the 1935 opera Porgy and Bess, but Janis Joplinâs cover is probably the best-known version. But Sonny and Cher did a version, too, and so did R.E.M.

20. âLove Yourselfâ // Justin Bieber

Co-written by Ed Sheeran and Benny Blanco, Bieberâs 2015 revenge smash really resonated with his fellow artists. Itâs been covered by Halsey (with slightly more explicit lyrics), Dua Lipa, Alessia Cara, and Dashboard Confessional. In fact, the song has been ranked just under âAll of Meâ as one of the most covered YouTube songs.

21. âBlackbirdâ // The Beatles

Another one of the prettiest Beatles songs, and another one of the most covered. In 2016, Foo Fighter Dave Grohl covered it, but there are also versions from Phish, Jesse McCartney, Bobby McFerrin, Eddie Vedder, and Elliott Smith.

22. âAmazing Graceâ // John Newton

Although the good people at Guinness World Records recognize âSummertimeâ as the most recorded song in history, they also note that âAmazing Graceâ has been recorded thousands of times, appearing on at least 11,000 albums. And itâs no wonderâthe song has been around since 1779, and the lyrics since 1772, when clergyman John Newton wrote the poem. And itâs not just popular at church; Judy Collinsâ version charted for 67 weeks between 1970 and 1972.

23. âThe Look Of Loveâ // Dusty Springfield

Written by Burt Bacharach and originally sung by Dusty Springfield for the first Casino Royale soundtrack in 1967, âThe Look of Loveâ has been covered a lot. Diana Ross, Gladys Knight, Nina Simone, Marvin Gaye, Shirley Bassey, and Diana Krall are just a few of the artists who have made it their own.

24. âWhite Christmasâ // Bing Crosby

Thanks to the ubiquitous holiday albums churned out by everyone from David Hasselhoff to Snoop Dogg, many holiday songs have the potential to make a âmost coveredâ list. But according to Billboard, Irving Berlinâs âWhite Christmas,â originally crooned by Bing Crosby, tops the list. The tune has been consistently covered since it was released in 1942, from Sinatra doing an early version in 1944 to Gwen Stefani covering it in 2017.

25. âSilent Nightâ // John Freeman Young

Another holiday entry on the list, FiveThirtyEight noted 26,496 âSilent Nightâ covers on Spotify aloneâmaking it not so silent after all. So what version is considered the best? Thatâs a matter of taste, of course, but in an Entertainment Weekly poll from 2013, readers chose the version by Kelly Clarkson, Trisha Yearwood, and Reba McEntire.

A version of this story ran in 2017; it has been updated for 2023.
